#Text=Chapter XIX
#Text=I had not announced my arrival to Stroeve , and when I rang the bell of his studio , on opening the door himself , for a moment he did not know me .
#Text=Then he gave a cry of delighted surprise and drew me in .
#Text=It was charming to be welcomed with so much eagerness .
#Text=His wife was seated near the stove at her sewing , and she rose as I came in .
#Text=He introduced me .
#Text="

#Text= And then to me : " But why did n't you let me know you were coming ?

column1: #Text=How long have you been here ?
#Text=How long are you going to stay ?
#Text=Why did n't you come an hour earlier , and we would have dined together ?

#Text= You have n't changed , " I said , smiling , as I looked at him .

column1: #Text=He had the same absurd appearance that I remembered .
#Text=He was a fat little man , with short legs , young still -- he could not have been more than thirty -- but prematurely bald .
#Text=His face was perfectly round , and he had a very high colour , a white skin , red cheeks , and red lips .
#Text=His eyes were blue and round too , he wore large gold-rimmed spectacles , and his eyebrows were so fair that you could not see them .
#Text=He reminded you of those jolly , fat merchants that Rubens painted .
#Text=When I told him that I meant to live in Paris for a while , and had taken an apartment , he reproached me bitterly for not having let him know .
#Text=He would have found me an apartment himself , and lent me furniture -- did I really mean that I had gone to the expense of buying it ?
#Text=-- and he would have helped me to move in .
#Text=He really looked upon it as unfriendly that I had not given him the opportunity of making himself useful to me .
#Text=Meanwhile , Mrs. Stroeve sat quietly mending her stockings , without talking , and she listened to all he said with a quiet smile on her lips .
#Text=" So , you see , I 'm married , " he said suddenly ; " what do you think of my wife ?

#Text= Really , Dirk , " put in Mrs. Stroeve , smiling .

column1: #Text="
#Text=, he said .
#Text=She flushed a little , embarrassed by the passion in his tone .
#Text=His letters had told me that he was very much in love with his wife , and I saw that he could hardly take his eyes off her .

#Text=I could not tell if she loved him . Poor pantaloon , he was not an object to excite love , but the smile in her eyes was affectionate , and it was possible that her reserve concealed a very deep feeling .
#Text=She was not the ravishing creature that his love-sick fancy saw , but she had a grave comeliness .
#Text=She was rather tall , and her gray dress , simple and quite well-cut , did not hide the fact that her figure was beautiful .
#Text=It was a figure that might have appealed more to the sculptor than to the costumier .
#Text=Her hair , brown and abundant , was plainly done , her face was very pale , and her features were good without being distinguished .
#Text=She had quiet gray eyes .
#Text=She just missed being beautiful , and in missing it was not even pretty .
#Text=But when Stroeve spoke of Chardin it was not without reason , and she reminded me curiously of that pleasant housewife in her mob-cap and apron whom the great painter has immortalised .

#Text=I could imagine her sedately busy among her pots and pans , making a ritual of her household duties , so that they acquired a moral significance ; I did not suppose that she was clever or could ever be amusing , but there was something in her grave intentness which excited my interest .
#Text=Her reserve was not without mystery .
#Text=I wondered why she had married Dirk Stroeve .
#Text=Though she was English , I could not exactly place her , and it was not obvious from what rank in society she sprang , what had been her upbringing , or how she had lived before her marriage .
#Text=She was very silent , but when she spoke it was with a pleasant voice , and her manners were natural .
#Text=I asked Stroeve if he was working .
#Text=" Working ?
